translation.en: about the world and how it works.
To prove that, we had to scan babies' brains.
translation.ko: 그걸 증명하려면 아기 뇌를 스캔해야 했어요

translation.en: But I couldn't do the scan when a baby was asleep.

translation.en: I needed the baby to be awake to see

translation.ko: 눈에 보이는 걸 어떻게 이해하고 배우는지 알 수 있었죠

translation.en: The problem was nobody had scanned awake babies before.
translation.ko: 문제는 깨어 있는 아기를 스캔한 사람이 전무했단 거예요

translation.en: The youngest awake brains we had seen were five years old.
And there is a good reason for that.
For an adult in an MRI machine,
translation.ko: 성인이 MRI 기계에 들어갈 때는 이렇게 얘기하면 돼요

translation.en: the way we do that experiment is we say, "Okay, lie down
translation.ko: 성인이 MRI 기계에 들어갈 때는 이렇게 얘기하면 돼요 '자, 이제부터 2시간 동안 꼼짝 말고 누워 계세요'

translation.en: and hold perfectly still for two hours, please."
translation.ko: '자, 이제부터 2시간 동안 꼼짝 말고 누워 계세요'

translation.en: There was no way a baby would last two hours.
translation.ko: 아기가 두 시간을 견딜 수 있을 리 없죠

translation.en: So the question was: what was the longest time a baby could last,
translation.ko: 그래서 아기가 견딜 수 있는 최대 시간과

translation.en: and what's the shortest time an MRI experiment could be,
translation.ko: MRI 영상을 찍을 수 있는 최소 시간의

translation.en: and was there any overlap?
The other problem with MRI is an MRI machine is really loud,
translation.ko: 또 다른 문제는 MRI 기계가 엄청 시끄럽거든요

translation.en: and we didn't want to damage a baby's developing hearing.
translation.ko: 아기의 청력 발달에 손상을 주면 안 되잖아요

translation.en: So we found a way to make the protocols
translation.ko: 그래서 뇌를 측정할 수 있을 정도로만

translation.en: less sensitive, in order to make them more quiet
and still have good enough measurements of the brain.
But that was really important.
We wanted to be sure that the baby's hearing would be safe.
For five years, we had been setting this experiment up.
So we sort of thought, "Okay, we have a protocol.
We have an experiment.
Maybe we're almost there.
All we need is babies."
And then I got pregnant.
When I first had Arthur,

How is it even possible

And then...
surprisingly, I kinda liked being his mother.

a really crazy, powerful satisfaction in being able to take care of him.
translation.ko: 아기를 돌보면서 너무도 크고 말도 안 되는 만족감을 느꼈어요

translation.en: And then it turned out
that one of the places I wanted to take care of him was inside an MRI machine.
translation.ko: MRI 기계 안에 같이 들어가면 되겠다고요

translation.en: Before I studied babies, I was studying adult brains.
translation.ko: 아기 뇌를  연구하기 전엔 성인의 뇌를 연구했어요

translation.en: Back then, we were looking for different brain regions doing different jobs.
translation.ko: 그때는 뇌의 어떤 영역이 어떤 일을 하는지 알아보고 있었죠

translation.en: In grown-ups, there are two brain regions that have really important jobs.
translation.ko: 성인들에게는 중요한 뇌의 영역이 두 개 있는데

translation.en: One is for seeing faces,
and the other one is for seeing scenes.
So we had this thought: could we see the same brain regions in babies?
translation.ko: 그래서 아기 뇌에서도 같은 영역을 볼 수 있을까 싶었죠

translation.en: So, we designed an experiment

translation.ko: 세 가지로 이루어진 엄청 단순한 실험인데

translation.en: It's three things:
the movies of faces;
happy, smiling, dynamic kids;
translation.ko: 아이들이 행복하게 웃는 여러 장면이 나오고요

translation.en: and then natural environments.
But then we need a baseline.
And so the baseline in between is scrambled up movies.
translation.ko: 그 기준선은 영상을 잘게 잘라 붙인 화면이었죠

translation.en: Then we tried to scan Arthur.
I'd be lying inside the scanner with the baby

and be like, "Come on, guys, come on, guys.
translation.ko: 그러면 저는 이런 심정이었어요 '그래, 바로 지금이야!'

translation.en: He's still! He's watching the movie!"
And then he would move.
So then we'd take him out of the scanner and we'd feed him.

translation.ko: 그렇게 두 시간을 보내면 집에 갔다가 다른 날 다시 와요

translation.en: and we'd go home for another day.
translation.ko: 집에 갔다가 다른 날 다시 와요

translation.en: Then we tried it again.
And again.
And again.
And I thought, "There's a good reason we don't know how babies' brains develop,
translation.ko: 그러다 이런 생각이 들었죠 아직도 아기 뇌 발달을 모르는 이유가 있구나

translation.en: because this is impossible."
I was trying to see if I could do this. Science takes a ton of...
emotional resilience, because most of the time...
something's not working.

translation.ko: 그래도 이걸 제대로 보거나 제대로 해낸

translation.en: to be the one who gets to do it for the first time.
Then a few days later, I'd be like,
"I really wanna know how his brain is developing."
translation.ko: 아기 뇌가 어떻게 발달하는지 정말 알고 싶어져요

translation.en: [laughs] And we would try again.
One day,
as we're scanning him,
and he's watching, and I would start to count in my head:
translation.ko: 애가 계속 보는 거예요 그래서 머리로 숫자를 셌죠

translation.en: get to "60... 23, 24, alright."
I was thinking,
"This might-- it might be working.

translation.ko: MRI 영상을 찍은 최초의 아이가 됐죠
